On 1 June, protests erupted across Shia-dominated areas of Bahrain to demand the end of martial law as the state of emergency was officially lifted.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/01/bahrain-protests-martial-law Bahrain sees new clashes as martial law lifted | World news | The Guardian<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Protests continued through early June, with demonstrators marching around the destroyed Pearl Roundabout, but security forces battled back and regularly dispersed demonstrators.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/201163135520207409.html|agency=Al Jazeera English|date=3 June 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011|title=Bahrain police 'suppress protest'}}</ref> The [[Bahrain Grand Prix]], a major [[Formula 1]] racing event, was officially canceled as the uprising wore on.<ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/06/bahrain-formula-1-boss-says-grand-prix-postponed.html?dlvrit=99665 BAHRAIN: Formula 1 boss says Grand Prix canceled] -''Los Angeles Times''.</ref> On 11 June, protest was announced in advance but did not receive government permission, opposition supporters said. It was held in the Shi'ite district of Saar, west of the capital. Police did not stop up to 10,000 people who came to the rally, many in cars, said a Reuters witness. Helicopters buzzed overhead.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/11/us-bahrain-idUSTRE75A19G20110611 Thousands of Bahrainis attended a rally for political reform on Saturday in the Gulf Arab state that crushed a pro-democracy protest movement in March.] ''-Reuters.''</ref> On 13 June, Bahrain's rulers commence the trials of 48 medical professionals, including some of the country's top surgeons, a move seen as the hounding of those who treated injured protesters during the popular uprising which was crushed by the military intervention of Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/201161373514815872.html |title=Bahrain medics on trial over protests - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-06-14}}</ref> ON June 18, The Bahraini government decided to life a ban on the largest opposition party.<ref>[http://lincolntribune.com/?p=14392 "Bahrain to lift ban on oppostion party", The Lincoln Tribune, June 18 2011], accessed 24 June 2011</ref> On 22 June, The Bahraini government sentences 10 pro-democracy activists to life in prison for their role in the uprising.<ref>{{cite web|author=Martin Chulov |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/22/bahraini-activists-jailed-life |title=Bahrain rights activists jailed for life | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/20116228219100399.html |title=Life sentences for Bahrain activists - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Bill Law |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13872206 |title=BBC News - Bahrain unrest: Eight Shia activists sentenced to life |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-06-23}}</ref>
